endings.title: GAME OVER: SILICON VALLEY SYNCHRONY
endings.subtitle: Apple - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Cupertino sun feels different when you aren't staring at it alone. Your badge is sleek, your MacBook is pristine, and your project on supply chain optimization for the next-gen hardware is actually being seen by VPs. But the real win is the quiet. After a ten-hour day of fighting SwiftUI bugs and logistics bottlenecks, you come home to them. You split overpriced Thai food and talk about things that aren't tech. They remind you that you’re a person, not just a resource. 

You’re finally in sync.
endings.s2:
You: first week at apple. i think i actually belong here?
Best Friend: i knew you’d kill it. how’s the partner liking the bay?
You: they love the weather. we found a boba spot near the office
Roommate: bro’s a corporate god now. don’t forget us peasants
You: never. but also, the cafeteria has 4 types of salmon
Best Friend: living the dream. proud of you for keeping it real.

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE GLASS CUBE
endings.subtitle: Apple - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
The campus is a masterpiece of glass and aluminum, a circular monument to the future. You’ve mastered the stack, your efficiency metrics are off the charts, and you’ve automated three of your weekly reporting tasks. But when the sun sets over the Santa Clara Valley, the silence in your studio apartment is deafening. You scroll through LinkedIn, looking at people you used to know, wondering if they’re as lonely as you are. You have the badge. You have the title. 

But the glass feels cold.
endings.s2:
You: got the return offer. it’s official
Roommate: big tech money!! let’s goooo
Best Friend: that’s huge. are you celebrating tonight?
You: just me and a bottle of wine. and some leetcode hards for fun
Best Friend: ...you need a hobby. or a person.
You: i have a career. that’s the same thing, right?
Roommate: big yikes.

endings.title: GAME OVER: AUTONOMOUS AFFECTION
endings.subtitle: Anduril - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
The desert heat is brutal, but the work is electric. You’re prototyping lattice systems and sensor arrays in a hangar that smells like jet fuel and high-end electronics. It’s 'militarized love'—you can't tell your partner what you're building, but they don't mind the NDAs. They meet you after work with cold water and a playlist that drowns out the hum of the drones. They don't care about the defense industry; they just care about you. 

In a world of automated threats, this feels safe.
endings.s2:
You: another 12 hour day. but we got the flight cert
Best Friend: you’re literally building iron man tech
You: lol basically. they made me lasagna tonight to celebrate
Roommate: simp. get me a drone that delivers beer
You: i’ll put it in the suggestion box
Best Friend: glad you have someone to ground you. that job sounds heavy.

endings.title: GAME OVER: GHOST IN THE MACHINE
endings.subtitle: Anduril - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You sign the NDAs without a second thought. You work in rooms without windows, solving problems that officially don't exist. Your technical depth is legendary among the cohort, and you’ve optimized the sensor calibration for the latest interceptor. But you can’t tell anyone. You sit at bars alone, listening to people complain about their 'boring' SaaS jobs, unable to share a single detail of your day. You’re building the future of defense. 

But you’re doing it from the shadows.
endings.s2:
You: can’t say what i did today but it was sick
Roommate: let me guess. more murder bots?
You: ...unmanned defense solutions.
Best Friend: sounds lonely. you even allowed to date people with that clearance?
You: i mean, technically yes. but who has the time?
Roommate: zero rizz. 100% lethality.

endings.title: GAME OVER: CAPITAL GAINS
endings.subtitle: JPMC - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
100-hour weeks in a glass tower in Manhattan. Your life is a blur of basis points, risk models, and the steady hum of the Bloomberg Terminal. But they are the only reason you remember what a Saturday feels like. They drag you out of the office for a walk in Central Park, forcing you to look at trees instead of spreadsheets. You’re moving markets by day and building a life by night. 

You’re winning—together.
endings.s2:
You: cleared $10k in bonus already. nyc is expensive though
Best Friend: insane. how’s the partner handling the 2am work calls?
You: they’re a saint. they actually learned what a 'straddle' is to help me vent
Roommate: bro found a keeper. buy them a rolex with that blood money
You: lol i bought them a nice dinner. that's a start.

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE QUANT SOLITUDE
endings.subtitle: JPMC - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You live by the terminal now. Your heart beats in basis points, and your social life has been replaced by high-frequency trading algorithms. You see the 'fat cats' of Wall Street every day, and you've become one of them—at least on paper. There’s no one waiting for you at home, but that’s okay. You have six monitors and a keyboard with no letters. You’re playing the game. 

And you're winning, even if the house is empty.
endings.s2:
You: just spent 16 hours on an ML model for credit risk
Roommate: you’re a literal robot
Best Friend: when was the last time you saw sunlight?
You: the monitor is 400 nits. that’s close enough
Roommate: enjoy your money, scrooge mcduck
You: i will. thanks.

endings.title: GAME OVER: YIELDING TO LOVE
endings.subtitle: TSMC - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Taiwan's semiconductor fabs run 24/7, and so do you. The cleanroom is your second home—white suit, mask, the hum of precision machinery. You're optimizing yield on wafers that'll power the next generation of chips. The work is meticulous, almost meditative. When you finally decompress in the evening, they're waiting. You send them photos of the process (redacted), they send you care packages of your favorite snacks. It's slow, methodical work in a country that never sleeps. 

But the foundation is solid.
endings.s2:
You: wafer batch hit 94% yield today. personal record
Best Friend: you're literally building the future
You: they're taking me to this night market place in Taipei tomorrow
Roommate: living the dream in taiwan
You: honestly? yeah. they make it worth it.

endings.title: GAME OVER: METICULOUS MILLIMETERS
endings.subtitle: TSMC - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
The fab never stops. You're deep in process control, tweaking variables at the nanoscale, chasing yields that determine whether your batch makes it to market. The air is filtered. The stakes are real. You've mastered the metrics, but mastery feels hollow when you clock out alone. Taiwan's night markets pulse around you, but you walk past them in silence, thinking about defect rates. 

You're building the chips that power the world. But the world doesn't know your name.
endings.s2:
You: density test failed. starting from batch zero
Roommate: when do you sleep?
You: sleep is for people with work-life balance
Best Friend: you're in Taiwan. go live a little
You: maybe after the next quarterly review.

endings.title: GAME OVER: LEGACY GRACE
endings.subtitle: IBM - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
It’s beige walls, old ThinkPads, and meetings where people still say 'synergy.' You’re rewriting COBOL wrappers for cloud services, and it’s not cool. But it’s stable. Your partner teases you about being a 'tech historian,' but they’re the one who makes you breakfast before your first day. In a volatile market, this stability feels like a miracle. 

Grace, in the form of a 401k and a hand to hold.
endings.s2:
You: updated a system older than my dad today
Best Friend: legend status. how’s the partner doing?
You: they’re good. we’re looking at apartments together
Roommate: corporate selling out looks good on you
You: stable income is a hell of a drug.

endings.title: GAME OVER: FORGOTTEN NAMES
endings.subtitle: IBM - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You aren't pushing the envelope; you’re duct-taping it. You quietly become indispensable among the grizzled ranks of engineers at Big Blue. No fanfare. No algorithmic glory. Just a paycheck, a title, and the quiet realization that you’ve become a 'computer guy' in a beige world. You go home to a quiet West Lafayette apartment, eat a frozen dinner, and watch K-pop videos until you fall asleep. 

Indispensable, yet invisible.
endings.s2:
You: taught myself lotus notes today. pray for me
Roommate: ancient tech unlock. you’re becoming a boomer
You: i have dental and a pension. i don’t care
Best Friend: still... sounds a bit lonely out there
You: it’s quiet. i like quiet.

endings.title: GAME OVER: SYSTEMS OF SUPPORT
endings.subtitle: RTX - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
The work is routine. CAN buses, firmware, and testing protocols in a windowless lab. You end most days sweaty and underappreciated, but when you walk through the door, they’re there. They bring you iced coffee and call the shop 'kinda cool, actually.' You don’t talk about changing the world. You just talk about your day. 

The machine keeps turning, and so do you.
endings.s2:
You: debugged a sensor issue. radar almost fried our pc lol
Best Friend: are YOU okay??
You: yeah, they made me lunch so i’m thriving
Roommate: fucking simp.
You: get laid.

endings.title: GAME OVER: COGS IN THE MACHINE
endings.subtitle: RTX - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You’re a head in the systems engineering pool. You write code for embedded systems no one talks about in the news. It’s not flashy or glamorous. You work in a factory line environment that smells like oil and ozone. You built something you can point to—something real—but there’s no one to show it to. You’re a cog, and the machine doesn’t care if you’re happy. 

As long as you’re functional.
endings.s2:
You: spent 6 hours on antenna calibration. feel like i aged 10 years
Roommate: try watching a chip fail post-silicon
Best Friend: you okay man? you sound tired
You: i’m surviving. just another day in the mines.

endings.title: GAME OVER: OPTIMIZED TRADEOFFS
endings.subtitle: BofA - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
You’re mostly optimizing credit flows and building dashboards for stakeholders who will never know your name. But your partner listens when you rant about APIs and vaguely predatory interest models. They get it—or at least, they’re trying. That means more than any promotion ever could. 

Cuffed and optimized.
endings.s2:
You: dashboard got 12 stakeholders to shut up. huge win
Best Friend: middle-manager appeasement arc
You: yeah, they bought me blue light glasses as 'combat gear'
Roommate: simp behavior but i respect the grind.

endings.title: GAME OVER: OPTIMALLY EMPTY
endings.subtitle: BofA - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
The tech’s modern, the meetings are constant, and your deliverables have deliverables. You spend half your day explaining your work to people who don't care. You feel... unfinished. Your parents brag about you at dinner parties, but you’re 'fine' in the way that means 'soul dead.' You have dental, you have a 401k, and you have a very large, very empty bed. 

Reagan wins again.
endings.s2:
You: watched a 14-slide deck about 'the cloud' that said nothing
Roommate: classic fintech. jump ship lil bro
Best Friend: you okay though? for real
You: i have a paycheck. i’m good.

endings.title: GAME OVER: INDUSTRIAL INTEGRATION
endings.subtitle: Siemens - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Industrial automation, PLC programming, and factory floor layouts. It’s not Silicon Valley, but it’s real. Your partner calls it 'heroic,' even if it’s just Google Sheets and synergy talks. They visit the shop once and think the robots are 'cute.' You don’t talk about impact. 

But the cars move, and you have someone to drive home to.
endings.s2:
You: 20% tech, 80% smiling at stakeholders today
Best Friend: consulting zzz. but glad you’re stable
You: they brought me coffee this morning. almost cried
Roommate: cringe. get me a factory discount.

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE AUTOMATION ARC
endings.subtitle: Siemens - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You’re in the 'fake tech mines.' Half your day is in Google Sheets, the other half is listening to people say 'agile' without flinching. It’s a way up, you suppose. But you don't believe in the work. You work in a windowless lab next to a factory line, and the only person who knows you're there is the security guard. 

Maybe this is enough. But you don't believe it.
endings.s2:
You: client asked if we could make the tool 'more synergy-focused'
Roommate: bro’s in consulting hell
Best Friend: i’m glad you have stability though
You: i’m surviving. that’s the goal, right?

endings.title: GAME OVER: SMALL VICTORIES
endings.subtitle: TechFlow - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
You're building dashboards for local businesses and fixing legacy PHP codebases that smell like 2009. The office is cramped, the tech stack is dated, but you're writing actual code. Your partner texts you after your first deployment: 'Proud of you.' You're not at a FAANG, but you're engineering solutions that real people use. 

It's not prestigious. But it's real.
endings.s2:
You: just shipped a CRM for a plumbing company. they loved it
Best Friend: that's actually awesome. real impact
You: they brought me lunch. said i 'saved their business'
Roommate: local legend. when's the wedding?

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE LOCAL LOOP
endings.subtitle: TechFlow - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You're the 'React guy' at a 12-person consulting shop. Your week was spent migrating a jQuery site to Next.js for a client who won't notice the difference. Nobody asks about your projects, and you don't bring them up. The checks clear. You aren't unemployed, which is a wild benchmark in this market. But you're just... there. 

Waiting for something that might never come.
endings.s2:
You: spent 8 hours fixing merge conflicts in someone else's spaghetti code
Roommate: lol you gonna be okay man?
Best Friend: you're doing what you have to. respect
You: trying not to forget who i am.

endings.title: GAME OVER: LOW PROFILE
endings.subtitle: Mason Defense - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
You write drivers for embedded systems no one talks about. Your partner thinks it’s cute how serious you get about antenna calibration. It’s not flashy or glamorous, but it’s solid. You meet for lunch sometimes, and for once, the lack of a 'prestige' company doesn't bother you. 

You have something better.
endings.s2:
You: spent 6 hours debugging an EOTS. aged 10 years
Best Friend: you’ll be fine. how’s the partner?
You: they packed me lunch. i almost proposed
Roommate: simp.

endings.title: GAME OVER: EMBEDDED OBSCURITY
endings.subtitle: Mason Defense - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
No all-nighters. No LinkedIn hustle. Just clean code and quiet wins. It’s not where you thought you’d be—you aren't at Lockheed or Boeing—but it’s yours. You clock out at 5:00 PM and walk into the cool Indiana evening. The silence is heavy, but the work is done. 

Solid. But lonely.
endings.s2:
You: its been chill. not glamorous, but solid
Roommate: describes 90% of hardware jobs
Best Friend: honestly that’s rare. hold onto it
You: i get to touch the RF stuff sometimes. cool i guess.

endings.title: GAME OVER: STEADY SHIP
endings.subtitle: Pinnacle CU - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Maintaining loan processing systems and patching legacy banking software that runs on COBOL. It's a credit union with 15 branches and a tech stack from 2007. But you're trusted with member data and financial systems that actually matter. Your partner brings you lunch and says they're proud of how far you've come. You believe them, even if no one else does. 

Stability feels like a real win.
endings.s2:
You: migrated 40k member accounts without data loss today
Roommate: fintech legend
Best Friend: i respect the grind. how's the partner?
You: they're the best. made the day bearable.

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE IT LEGEND
endings.subtitle: Pinnacle CU - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
You're maintaining a lending platform built on FoxPro and writing SQL queries for compliance reports. The credit union treats you like a wizard because you understand REST APIs. You're 'one of the sharper ones' here, but that's not a high bar. You go home to an empty room and wonder if your degree was worth it. 

Indispensable in a world that's standing still.
endings.s2:
You: explained what an API is to my manager three times today
Roommate: ancient tech unlock. you're becoming a boomer
Best Friend: still... sounds a bit lonely out there
You: at least the pension is real.

endings.title: GAME OVER: PROTOTYPING PEACE
endings.subtitle: Apex Comp. - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Industrial resin, topology optimization, and 200-micron tolerances. You spend your days prototyping parts no one’s ever built before. Your partner sends playlists while you work, and you send videos of prints failing in spectacular fashion. It’s slow, honest work. 

Something worth building.
endings.s2:
You: got my first part approved for flight cert
Best Friend: THIS IS HUGE
You: they brought me coffee. almost cried
Roommate: cringe.

endings.title: GAME OVER: MANUAL LABOR
endings.subtitle: Apex Comp. - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
The lab smells like melted filament and caffeine. You run tests. You fail prints. You iterate. You're making something permanent, but you don't have someone to celebrate with. You're proud anyway, but the fridge at home is empty of everything but leftovers. 

Blue collar rizz, but no one to see it.
endings.s2:
You: 28-hour print collapsed. don’t care. design passed anyway
Best Friend: lowkey thriving out there
Roommate: industrial L
You: cope. i built a real part.

endings.title: GAME OVER: PUBLIC GRACE
endings.subtitle: Municipal - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
It’s not tech. It’s civil service. You fixed a city's Wi-Fi contract and they think you’re a hero. Your partner believes it, too. Stability feels like a real win after the chaos of the semester. You spend your weekends at the park, not in the lab. 

You found your footing.
endings.s2:
You: city council thanked me personally lol
Best Friend: you’re a local celebrity
You: they took me out to dinner to celebrate. feels good
Roommate: govtech simp.

endings.title: GAME OVER: BUREAUCRACY BLUES
endings.subtitle: Municipal - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
Resetting passwords and fixing printer jams. You're the sharpest person in the building, but the building is falling apart. You feel like you're LARPing as an engineer. You go home alone and wonder if you'll ever do 'real' work. 

One of the sharper ones. In a room of none.
endings.s2:
You: i just spent 3 hours on a printer jam
Roommate: lol stay mad
Best Friend: it’s a job. keep your head up
You: trying.

endings.title: GAME OVER: THE LAB ROMANCE
endings.subtitle: Paid Research - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
Late nights in the political science department. There’s no funding and no recognition, but they bring you coffee when the experiments drag past midnight. You’re running tests, fixing broken scripts, and figuring things out together. 

Something real.
endings.s2:
You: pi said 'huh.' that’s the win for today
Best Friend: scientist arc! how’s the partner helping?
You: they’re the only reason i haven't lost my mind
Roommate: hazard pay needed.

endings.title: GAME OVER: INTERN, INTERRUPTED
endings.subtitle: Paid Research - Partner (No)
endings.s1:
Your name is misspelled on a poster that might be presented in Belgium. You don’t get paid. You don’t get credit. But for the first time, you feel like you’re part of something that might outlast you. Even if the room is empty when you leave at 2 AM. 

You’ll remember this summer. Even if no one else does.
endings.s2:
You: code’s going into a paper. that’s kinda cool
Roommate: as long as it’s not just acknowledgments
Best Friend: i’m proud of you regardless
You: thanks. i think i needed that.

endings.title: GAME OVER: FRESH BREATHS
endings.subtitle: Nothing - Partner (Yes)
endings.s1:
The inbox stayed quiet. The calendar stayed empty. But the world didn't end. You help them cook. You go on walks. You finally read that book you kept pretending to finish. It still stings, yeah. But you’re breathing. 

And for now, that’s enough.
endings.s2:
You: no luck this cycle. just gonna take the L
Best Friend: rest. rebuild. you’ve earned both
You: they said they're proud of me anyway. why am i crying?
Roommate: they're a real one.

endings.title: GAME OVER: DREAMS DEFERRED
endings.subtitle: Nothing - Partner (No) (Canon Ending)
endings.s1:
You sleep in. Scroll past sunrise. Apply to jobs that don’t reply. The semester's over, and you're back in West Lafayette with nothing to show for it. You tell yourself it’s temporary. That the market’s broken. But you don’t believe it. You just close the tab and lie back down in tears. 

Survival is the only goal left.
endings.s2:
You: no internships. nothing
Best Friend: i’m really sorry man
Roommate: we still got you
You: i know. just wish that was enough.

endings.title: GAME OVER: QUESTIONABLE RETURN ON INVESTMENT
endings.subtitle: The Offramp (Business School)
endings.s1:
You’re in business school now. There’s a bitter convenience to it; a preordained pipeline for the kids who were once gifted and tired. No one asks why you gave up on engineering. You just... stopped. Now you talk about 'leverage' and 'synergy' like it’s a religion. You let the fire go out. 

And sometimes, you swear you can still feel the ghost of who you used to be.
endings.s2:
You: networking event today. free shrimp was the only highlight
Roommate: you’ve changed. you used to build stuff
Best Friend: now you just build debt
You: stfu i’m networking.
